concept_intro: CLAUDE.md is a configuration file that gives Claude context about your project. It's automatically loaded every conversation, so Claude always knows your preferences.
options: Project context and preferences that persist across sessions
explanation: CLAUDE.md provides persistent context - project structure, coding standards, and preferences. It's loaded automatically every time you start Claude Code.

concept_intro: The /init command analyzes your codebase and generates a starter CLAUDE.md automatically. Review and refine it based on your team's actual practices.
question_text: What command generates a CLAUDE.md file for your project?
explanation: Run /init and Claude will analyze your codebase to generate a starter CLAUDE.md. Review the output and refine it to match your team's actual practices.

concept_intro: The filename must be exactly CLAUDE.md (uppercase CLAUDE, lowercase .md). Case sensitivity matters - claude.md won't work.
question_text: What is the correct capitalization for the config file?
explanation: The file must be exactly CLAUDE.md - uppercase CLAUDE with lowercase .md extension. Case matters for Claude Code to recognize and load it.

concept_intro: CLAUDE.local.md is for personal preferences you don't want in version control. Add it to .gitignore - it won't be shared with your team.
question_text: How do you store personal preferences without committing them?
options: Use CLAUDE.local.md and add it to .gitignore
explanation: CLAUDE.local.md stores personal preferences. Add it to .gitignore so your individual settings don't get shared with the team's version control.

concept_intro: Place CLAUDE.md at ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md for settings that apply to ALL your projects. It acts as your personal default configuration.
question_text: Where do you put CLAUDE.md for global settings across all projects?
explanation: ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md provides global defaults that apply to all your projects. Project-level CLAUDE.md files can override these settings.

concept_intro: Keep your CLAUDE.md concise! Every line competes for attention with your actual work. Long files waste tokens that could be used for coding.
question_text: Why should CLAUDE.md be kept concise?
options: Every line consumes tokens from your context window
explanation: Context is precious - every line in CLAUDE.md uses tokens that could go to your actual work. Delete filler content that doesn't add strategic value.

concept_intro: Don't put code style rules in CLAUDE.md - use linters instead. Linters enforce rules automatically, while CLAUDE.md suggestions can be inconsistent.
question_text: What should you NOT put in CLAUDE.md?
options: Detailed code formatting rules (use linters instead)
explanation: Don't duplicate what linters do better. Use ESLint, Prettier, or similar tools for code style. CLAUDE.md is for project context, not formatting rules.

concept_intro: Never put sensitive information like API keys in CLAUDE.md. It becomes part of Claude's context and could be shared or exposed.
question_text: What should NEVER go in CLAUDE.md?
explanation: Never put secrets in CLAUDE.md! It's loaded into Claude's context every session. Use .env files and environment variables for sensitive data.

concept_intro: Use emphasis keywords like 'IMPORTANT' or 'YOU MUST' for critical instructions. Claude pays more attention to emphasized rules.
question_text: How can you make Claude follow critical rules more reliably?
options: Put it at the end of the file
Use all caps for the entire file
explanation: Keywords like 'IMPORTANT' and 'YOU MUST' signal critical instructions. Claude is trained to pay more attention to emphasized rules.

concept_intro: Claude Code has a 200K context window. Your CLAUDE.md, conversation history, and file contents all compete for this space.
question_text: What is Claude Code's context window limit?
explanation: Claude Code has a 200K token context window. Your CLAUDE.md, conversation, and files all share this space. Use /compact when you run low.

concept_intro: MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers extend Claude's capabilities, but each one consumes context. Too many MCPs can shrink usable context from 200K to 70K.
question_text: How can too many MCPs affect your context window?
options: They can shrink usable context from 200K to 70K
They have no effect on context
explanation: Each MCP server consumes context tokens. Too many enabled MCPs can reduce your usable context from 200K to as low as 70K. Keep under 10 active per project.

concept_intro: The .mcp.json file in your repo makes MCP tools available to all team members automatically. Configure MCP servers there for shared team access.
question_text: How do you share MCP configurations with your team?
options: Create a .mcp.json file in your repo
explanation: A checked-in .mcp.json file makes MCP tools available to all team members automatically when they work on the project.

concept_intro: In monorepos, you can have nested CLAUDE.md files. Parent directories provide shared context, while subdirectories can have package-specific overrides.
question_text: How do CLAUDE.md files work in monorepos?
options: Nested files provide shared and package-specific context
Only the root CLAUDE.md is read
Only the deepest CLAUDE.md is read
explanation: In monorepos, Claude reads CLAUDE.md files from parent directories down. Root provides shared context, subdirectories add package-specific instructions.

concept_intro: Use 'disabledMcpServers' in your project .claude/settings.json to turn off specific MCPs for a project without uninstalling them globally.
question_text: How do you disable specific MCPs for one project only?
options: Delete the MCP from your global config
MCPs can only be disabled globally
explanation: Add disabledMcpServers to your project's .claude/settings.json. This turns off specific MCPs for that project without affecting your global configuration.

concept_intro: For complex tasks, create scratchpad files to plan before implementing. Claude can track progress in a markdown file, preserving context across sessions.
question_text: What's a good technique for planning complex multi-session tasks?
options: Use scratchpad markdown files to track progress
Create a new session for each step
explanation: Create markdown scratchpad files to plan complex tasks. Claude can update them as you progress, and they persist across sessions unlike conversation history.
